chargeHist.descr: Take and Drive Vehicle w/o Consent

result.execSummary:
The defendant William Byrne was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case. One or more other charges in this case were dismissed. The dismissed charges were not proven and have no legal effect. William Byrne is presumed innocent of the dismissed charges.

  • William Byrne was found guilty of Take and Drive Vehicle w/o Consent, a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 943.23(2).
  • William Byrne was found guilty of Credit Card-Fraudulent Use (>$10,000), a class G felony, Wisconsin Statutes 943.41(5)(a).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

parties.name: Kenosha County Clerk of Circuit Court

miscConds.notes:
Obey all of the rules and regulations of supervising probation agent.  Pay supervision fees.  Do not possess or consume alcoholic beverages and do not have alcoholic beverages within the residence.  Do not possess or consume controlled substances, except by prescription.  Participate in counseling deemed appropriate by your agent, which may include: alcohol/drug, anger management/DV counseling, psychiatric/psychological, AODA Assessment and follow-through with recommended treatment.
**  Pay all court costs including all applicable surcharges.
Submit a DNA sample (unless previously provided).
** Pay DNA surcharge (unless previously paid).
** Pay restitution plus surcharges.  May have contact with Erickson family if they request it.  Review hearing on 10/12/15 @ 1:30.  RE:  Payment of restitution.
If restitution is not paid in full at the end of the 5 yr term of probaiton, judgment will be entered against the deft or his estate.
